si1.gif gif 673 50 212 ALTIMG APCATA 16600 S0926-860X(18)30145-5 10.1016/j.apcata.2018.03.026 Fig. 1 Comparison of toluene conversion activity over X wt%MO + 0.77 wt%(Ni68Fe32) (MO = MgO, CaO, SrO, BaO ; X is equimolar to 0.4 wt% MgO) catalysts containing various alkaline earth metal oxides over a range of temperatures (GHSV = 12,990 cc g−1 h−1). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Optimization of toluene conversion activity with varying Ni/(Ni + Fe) ratios in 0.4 wt%MgO + 0.77 wt%(NiFe) catalysts, in which total weight of NiFe was nearly 0.77 wt% (GHSV = 12,990 cc g−1 h−1; Temperature–650 °C). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Optimization of toluene conversion activity with variation in MgO content in (a) Ni-Fe-MgO and (b) Ni-MgO catalyst compositions, in which 0.77 wt%(Ni68Fe32) and 1 wt%Ni were constant, respectively (GHSV = 12,990 cc g−1 h−1 ; Temperature–650 °C). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Effect of calcination temperatures on C7H8 conversion as well as H2/CO ratio at different temperatures over 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34)/Carbo HSP catalyst (GHSV = 12,990 cc gcat −1 h−1; Time of calcination–24 h). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 C7H8 conversion and H2/CO ratio vs Temperature at different H2O concentration in producer gas over 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34)/Carbo HSP catalyst (GHSV = 12,990 cc g−1 h−1). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 C7H8 conversion at different H2O concentrations in producer gas over 1.15%(Fe72Mg28)/Carbo HSP catalyst (GHSV = 12,990 cc g−1 h−1). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Time-on-Stream study over 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34)/Carbo HSP catalyst with producer gas at 750 °C (a) and 639 °C (b). (GHSV = 12,990 cc g−1 h−1). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The comparison of (a) toluene and (b) benzene conversion activity between 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34)/Carbo HSP and the reference catalysts 1.15%(Ni41Mg27K32)/Carbo HSP over a range of temperatures in separate experiments. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (A) XRD patterns of catalysts on Carbo HSP support in reduced form (a) Carbo HSP, (b) 0.75%Ni, (c) 1.15%(Fe72Mg28), (d) 1.15%(Ni72Mg28), (e) 0.77%(Ni68Fe32), (f) Fresh 1.17%(Fe45Fe21Mg34) and (g) Spent 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) ; (B) XRD patterns of in reduced form without Carbo HSP support, (a) 1.15%(Ni72Mg28), (b) 1.15%(Fe72Mg28), (c) 1.17%(Fe45Fe21Mg34) catalysts. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 TPR profiles of (a) Carbo HSP, (b) 0.75%Ni, (c) 0.75%Fe, (d) 0.77%(Ni68Fe32), (e) 1.15%(Ni72Mg28), (f) 1.15%(Fe72Mg28) and (g) 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) impregnated catalysts. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 SEM images of freshly reduced samples of (a) 0.75%Ni, (b) 0.77%(Ni68Fe32), (c) 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34), and (d) spent 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34). Cattolica ⁎ Reinhard Seiser Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of California San Diego, 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, CA 92093, United States Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering University of California San Diego 9500 Gilman Drive La Jolla CA 92093 United States ⁎ Corresponding author at: 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, CA 92093-0411, United States. Graphical abstract Ni-Fe-Mg catalyst showed much higher tar conversion activity in producer gas mixture as compared with Ni-K-Mg reference catalyst. A Ni-Fe-Mg material, supported on a ceramic substrate, suitable for application in a gasifier or reforming reactor was evaluated as a catalyst for tar decomposition via steam reforming. Experiments were conducted in a laboratory-scale fixed-bed reactor using simulated producer gas containing toluene and ethylene as tar surrogates. The catalyst was prepared by wet-impregnation and characterized by analytical techniques to include: BET, XRD, TPR, and SEM. The elemental composition of Ni, Fe, and MgO was optimized for maximum activity and stability. The optimized catalyst composition contained Ni, Fe, and MgO in the ratio 45:21:34 by weight. The observed catalyst activity was superior in comparison to other alkaline earth metal promoters: CaO, SrO, and BaO as well as a reference catalyst, Ni-K-MgO, in the temperature range between 600 and 800 °C. Time on stream with the optimized composition showed sustained tar (toluene + ethylene) conversion of near 100% at 750 °C for at least 48 h, indicating no coke formation. The coke formation affinity of Ni was reduced by the presence of the FeNi3 alloy. The enhanced performance with MgO is attributed to the strong adsorption of H2O forming Mg(OH)2 species facilitated on the oxide ion vacancy site of MgO acting as oxygen exchange site. Keywords Gasifier bed material Magnesium oxide Producer gas Steam reforming Toluene Tars 1 Introduction The utilization of fossil fuels and the resulting negative impact on the environment has stimulated the development of renewable-energy resources, including the use of abundant biomass materials. Biomass can be thermo-chemically converted by gasification into producer gas which can be used in the production of power, fuels, and chemicals through various reactions [1]. The major components in producer gas mixture are: H2, CO, CO2, H2O, CH4, C2-C5 hydrocarbons, tars, NH3, and H2S. The condensable tars which include various aromatic hydrocarbons can cause severe fouling and corrosion problems. Therefore, a tar-free producer gas is required for downstream chemical-conversion processes. Biomass gasification in a dual fluidized-bed (DFB) reactor is a feasible approach for the production of a nitrogen-free producer gas [2–4]. Gas cleaning prior to downstream conversion processes is important and should be economically viable. Among the necessary removable components, tars can be removed with a catalyst-coated bed material during gasification itself and this step is the simplest and most cost-effective method [5–7]. Non-catalyzed bed materials such as olivine, dolomite, silica sand, and limestone have been used in gasifiers, but these are not active enough to reduce tar content significantly [8–13]. If the bed material is impregnated with a catalyst, tar content can be significantly reduced during the gasification process. Pure Ni catalyst suffers coke formation, leading to deactivation of the catalyst as well as sintering of Ni particles at high temperature. Improved Ni-catalyst performance can be obtained by alloying with other metals, or using an oxide promoter in the catalyst formulation. There has been research on Ni-catalyst formulations using promoter metals such as Cu, Mo, Co, and Fe [14–23]. The addition of Fe into Ni has been found to be beneficial due to the formation of an alloy [24–28]. The role of Fe in contact with Ni is to accumulate the oxygen, by virtue of mild redox capacity, for oxidation of coke species from the metal surface [25,29]. Therefore, high catalytic performance was observed in Ni–Fe/Mg/Al catalysts due to presence of highly dispersed Ni–Fe alloy particles [26]. A number of oxide promoters have been used for Ni and Ni-Fe combinations. The addition of a redox component like CeO2 enhanced the activity of Ni as well as Ni-Fe alloys [30–39]. The oxide vacancy site on CeO2 acting as a H2O adsorption and desorption center could be responsible for the higher activity. Alkaline earth metal oxides like CaO have been a useful promoter for Ni-Fe, Ni-Al2O3, or Ni-Fe-Al2O3 catalysts leading to higher activity for steam reforming reactions [40–42]. Similarly, Ca-containing Mayenite (Ca12Al14O33 or 12CaO.7Al2O3) supported Ni showed good activity and stability [43]. Baidya et al. reported the promotion of Ni-Fe alloy in the presence of CaO [44]. The presence of alkaline earth promoters and Fe together can enhance the activity and stability of Ni catalysts. Ni impregnated on natural olivine has improved catalytic activity for tar decomposition [45]. The characterization of Ni/Olivine revealed that Ni can interact with Fe and MgO and enhance the activity [46]. Nakamura et al. reported the promoting effect of MgO in Ni-based catalysts [47]. It showed that MgO helps dispersion of Ni through forming NiO-MgO solid solution. Similarly, Ni/Fe/Mg/Al-containing catalysts showed promising results for toluene reforming as compared to other Ni-based catalysts [48–50]. Although Ni-Fe alloys have been supported on Mg-Al oxide mixtures obtained from hydrotalcite composition, the positive role of MgO along with a Ni-to-Fe ratio in the Ni-Fe alloy has not been optimized. This has motivated the development of a catalyst containing the optimum Ni-Fe-MgO composition to utilize the full potential of MgO as a promoter and its use on gasifier bed material. This study reports a catalyst consisting of a Ni-Fe-MgO mixture with optimization of the components on a gasifier support (Carbo HSP) to obtain the highest activity for tar decomposition via steam reforming in producer gas, containing toluene as tar component. 2 Methods 2.1 Catalysts preparation Ni, Fe, Ni-MgO, and Ni-Fe-MgO mixed oxides catalysts were prepared on a Carbo HSP support by wet-impregnation method. The elemental composition of the commercial support material was: 83% Al2O3 7% Fe2O3, 5.0% SiO2, 3.5% TiO2, and 1.5% others. The components of the impregnated Ni-Fe-MgO catalysts were varied with the goal of obtaining the highest catalytic activity. Stoichiometric amounts of precursor salts including Ni(NO3)2.6H2O, Fe(NO3)3.9H2O, and Mg(NO3)2.6H2O were dissolved in minimum volume of water to a transparent solution and then 20 g of pre-calcined Carbo HSP support was poured into the solution with continuous stirring until the whole surface was wet. The support impregnated with catalyst precursor solution was maintained for 6 h at room temperature and then processed in a furnace at 110 °C for 12 h. The temperature was increased by a rate of 50 ° per 15 min dwelling at each point up to 850 °C and then maintained at this temperature for 12 h. The metal salts were decomposed at high temperature to the corresponding oxides giving NiO, FeOx, and MgO mixtures. Total loading on a metals/metal-oxide basis was between 0.75 and 1.25% by weight. The list of catalysts with calculated weights of Ni, Fe, and MgO components taken during preparation are a presented in Table 1 . The nomenclature of 0.77%(Ni68Fe32) indicates a Ni:Fe ratio of 68:32 by weight with a total loading of 0.77%. Similarly, in 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34), the Ni:Fe:MgO ratio was 45:21:34 by weight with a total loading of 1.17%. For a comparison, CaO, SrO, and BaO containing samples were also prepared. In these oxides, CaO, SrO, and BaO were loaded in an equivalent molar quantity of 0.4 wt% MgO. The common support Carbo HSP is not referenced in the catalyst formulation description. For comparison, a formulation corresponding to the NREL 60 catalyst, using 1.15%(Ni41Mg27K32), was considered as a reference catalyst for this study. The reference catalyst was prepared following the procedure described in the literature [51]. This catalyst contained Ni:MgO:K2O ratio of 41:27:32 by weight, since Mg and K always remain in the oxide form. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen physisorption and surface area were measured in a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 Instrument at 77 K. The samples were outgassed for 1 h under vacuum at 400 °C before the measurements, and the specific surface area (SSA) was determined using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was measured with an X-ray diffractometer (BRUKER D2 PHASER) equipped with a monochromator for Cu Kα radiation at a voltage of 30 kV, and a current of 100 mA. The impregnated catalysts were measured from 2θ = 20 to 60° with a step size of 0.02°. The XRD data was analyzed using the International Centre for Diffraction Data (ICDD) database. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) studies were performed with a Quantachrome Instrument (ChemBET-3000 TPR/TPD). For this experiment, 500 mg of the catalyst was loaded in a U-shaped quartz tube reactor. Before the TPR experiment, the sample was outgassed under N2 flow at 400 °C for 1 h and allowed to cool down to room temperature. Then, the reactor temperature was ramped from 40 to 800 °C at 10 °C/min under 3% H2/N2. The amount of reduction was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature-programmed Desorption (TPD) studies were carried out in the same Quantachrome Instrument (ChemBET-3000 TPR/TPD). For this experiment, 100 mg of MgO containing catalyst was loaded (molar equivalent for other promoters) in a U-shaped quartz tube reactor. Before the TPD experiment, the sample was outgassed under N2 flow at 850 °C for 1 h and allowed cool down to 100 °C. CO2 was passed over the catalyst for 1 h and again changed to N2 flow. After signal stabilization in N2 flow, the reactor temperature was ramped from 100 °C to 900 °C at 10 °C/min. The scanning electron microscopic study was carried out with a Phillips XL30 to look into the microstructures in the surface. Fourier-Transform Infrared spectra were carried out with attenuated total reflectance (ATR) attachment (Nicolet 6700 with Smart-iTR diamond ATR crystal) using liquid nitrogen-cooled MCT-A detector. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic steam reforming reactions were carried out in a fixed-bed flow reactor reported in a previous study [29]. In this investigation, 2.0 g of catalyst was mixed with quartz chips (1/16″) in a ratio of 1:10 (by wt.). The mass transfer limitation is expected to remain negligible considering the non-porous nature of the catalysts. The catalysts were activated by reducing the metal oxides in H2 flow at 850 °C for 1 h in the reactor raising the bed temperature with ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. The reactor was then cooled down in N2 flow to below 800 °C. The steam reforming was carried out between 650 °C and 800 °C with the total flow rate of 433 sccm maintained including H2O in gaseous state referenced to STP (0 °C, 1 atm). The process of regeneration of used catalyst was done by the following steps: (1) re-oxidation in pure O2 for 1 h at 800 °C, (2) purged with N2, and then (3) reduced again in H2 for 1 hr at 800 °C. The composition of feed gas was similar to that of raw producer gas [52]. The producer gas composition (mol %) was: 13.4% H2, 25.3% CO, 6.4% CO2, 9.8% CH4, 3.9% C2H4, 40.4% H2O and 0.9% C7H8. In the study, the producer gas mixture was diluted with N2 giving a final composition as: 10.6% H2, 19.9% CO, 5.23% CO2, 7.8% CH4, 3.17% C2H4, 31.7% H2O, 0.74% C7H8 and 21.7% N2. The C7H8 content in the gas mixture is 35.7 g Nm−3, similar to the tar content as reported in the producer gas obtained from fluidized-bed gasification [53]. The outlet gas composition was analyzed with micro-gas chromatography, and the volume corrections were made with N2 reference. The conversion of any reacting component is determined by the following expression: The percent conversion for a reactant A, i.e., %, is calculated by: X A % = m o l A i n − m o l A o u t m o l A i n X 100 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic results The promotion of the activity of Ni and Ni-Fe with MgO for tar reforming was investigated with toluene as a model tar surrogate. The comparison of the toluene-conversion activity over MgO, CaO, SrO, and BaO promoted Ni-Fe catalysts is shown in Fig. 1 . In all these catalysts, CaO, SrO, and BaO were included in amounts equimolar to the 0.4 wt% MgO in a 0.77% Ni68Fe32 composition. The MgO-promoted catalyst is much more active, notably in the lower temperature range, than the other promoters with the trend as following: MgO >> CaO > SrO > BaO. This indicates that MgO is a significant promoter for Ni-Fe metals. It should be noted that the BaO-promoted sample has a lower conversion as compared to pure Ni. This significant difference in toluene-conversion activity with MgO requires further investigation to elucidate its unique role. The ratio of the components in Ni-Fe-MgO-based catalysts was optimized for toluene- conversion activity. Initially, an optimum Ni:Fe ratio was determined by varying the Ni/Fe ratio in a 0.4 wt%MgO + 0.77 wt%(NiFe) catalyst (see Table 1). In Fig. 2 , a plot of toluene conversion versus Ni/(Ni + Fe) ratios in the above catalyst is shown. Toluene conversion reaches a maximum of 86% at Ni/(Ni + Fe) ratio of 0.68 and then slowly decreases. Therefore, further studies were carried out with the 0.4 wt% MgO + 0.77 wt% (Ni68Fe32) composition. This composition is represented as 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34). The optimization of the ratio of MgO addition into the Ni-Fe mixture was determined from the plot of toluene conversion versus MgO/(Ni + Fe) ratio as shown in Fig. 3 a. MgO significantly promotes the toluene-conversion activity with increasing MgO content and reaches a maximum at the ratio of 0.53. The promoting effect of MgO was also tested on pure Ni to examine the role of Fe in the Ni-Fe-MgO catalysts. Although those catalysts (Ni-MgO composition) were very active at higher temperatures, the activity at lower temperatures was low (Fig. 3b). Toluene conversion was not significant, remaining at 32% at 650 °C. At the end of the reaction study, a significant amount of black coke was observed to have been formed in the catalyst bed. The deposited coke could be responsible for the lower activity due to blocking of active Ni sites in the Ni-MgO catalysts, unlike the Ni-Fe-MgO catalysts. The effect of calcination on the catalytic activity of 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) was tested at different calcination temperatures between 850 °C and 950 °C as shown in Fig. 4 . The tar conversion was only slightly affected at 950 °C, indicating significant stability of the catalyst. H2O in producer gas acts as an oxidant for converting carbon species into COx products. The effect of water concentration on toluene conversion activity on 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) catalyst was tested between 530 °C and 800 °C and is shown in Fig. 5 . The difference was visible below 700 °C, which indicates that both toluene conversion as well as H2/CO ratio increased with increasing H2O concentration from 15.8% to 31.5%. Coke deposition was visible in the catalyst bed with a blackish color at 15.8% H2O. Therefore, at least 20% H2O concentration is essential for maintaining the catalyst activity without coke formation. This was further confirmed by TPO results (Temperature Programmed Oxidation), which showed less coke in the samples with higher water content. A comparison was made with 1.15%(Fe72Mg28) catalyst, showing very poor activity as presented in Fig. 6 and there was only small change after the H2O concentration was reduced from 31.6% to 17.2%. The Fe based catalyst also did not show any sign of coke formation. The 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) catalyst was tested for time on stream as shown in Fig. 7 a. The toluene conversion was near 100%, and remained nearly unchanged for at least 48 h. Similarly, C2H4 conversion was stable near 93% during the test. The inlet-gas mixture contained a H2/CO ratio of 0.51 and giving initially a ratio of 1.5 in the outlet gas, which slowly increased to a stable ratio of 1.75 during time on stream. No deactivation in tar conversion was observed unlike the previous Ni-based catalysts [39,45]. The catalyst color did not change, indicating no coke deposition on the catalyst. This was further confirmed by TPO, which did not show any signal. A similar experiment was also carried out at a temperature of 639 °C with lower toluene conversion. The initial toluene conversion of 75% reduced slightly and remained stable at 70% at the end of 30 h of time on stream (Fig. 7b). A comparison of the activity of the 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) catalyst was made with a reference catalyst. The composition of the reference catalyst includes: Ni–6.1%, Mg–2.4% and K–4% by weight [51]. To normalize the catalytic activity, 1.15% of the reference catalyst was impregnated on CARBO HSP. The conversion of C7H8 at different temperatures over the two catalysts is presented in Fig. 8 a, with much higher toluene conversion over 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) in comparison to the reference catalyst. The comparison was further extended to benzene (Fig. 8b), again showing higher conversion for the 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) catalyst. The results indicate that the catalyst is more effective in reforming toluene than benzene. Toluene is an electron rich material due to the presence of an electron-donating methyl group unlike the highly symmetrical benzene molecule. The toluene molecule has some polarity and is reactive in being oxidized by oxygen species over Ni-based catalysts in comparison with the non-polar benzene molecule. 3.2 Catalyst characterizations 3.2.1 BET surface area A BET surface area measurement of the pure Carbo HSP support did not produce a measureable result, despite the sensitivity of the instrument. The 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34)/Carbo HSP catalyst produced a value of 0.03 m2/g. The same instrument was tested on a reference γ-Alumina sample with a measured surface area at the low value of 0.6 m2/g. The surface area of the Carbo HSP support was extremely low for the 400 micron size spherical shape. 3.2.2 XRD analysis XRD profiles of pure Carbo HSP support as well as catalyst 0.75%Ni, 1.15%(Fe72Mg28), 1.15%(Ni72Mg28), 0.77%(Ni68Fe32), and 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) impregnated on the Carbo HSP support are presented in Fig. 9 . Since the catalytic studies were carried out after reducing the oxide components with hydrogen, the XRD samples were also ex-situ reduced before measurement. The probable phases related to the metals Ni, Fe, NiFe alloy or Mg oxide were analyzed with respect to the reduced Carbo HSP as background (Fig. 9(A)a). The maximum intense peaks at 44.6° and 51.9° corresponds to (111) and (110) planes of Ni metal on Carbo HSP surface (Fig. 9(A)b). With the addition of MgO into 0.75%Ni/Carbo HSP and 0.75%Fe/Carbo HSP (Fig. 9(A) c and d), the observed intensities from Ni and Fe metals were different despite having similar amount of metal loading. The Fe metal detected at 44.82° for (110) plane in Fe/Carbo remained similar to that in 1.15%(Fe72Mg28) (Fig. 9(A)c). The intensity of Ni (111) was significantly reduced in 1.15%(Ni72Mg28) catalyst (Fig. 9(A)d) in comparison to pure Ni loading (Fig. 9(A)b). By comparing main peak intensity of 0.75%Ni/Carbo catalyst (containing similar amount of Ni), it was found that 58% of the NiO could be reduced, while the remaining 42% formed a solid solution with MgO. The mixture of Fe and Ni in 0.77%(Ni68Fe32) led to formation of a new phase, in which peak position shifted to lower 2θ at 44° (marked by * in Fig. 9(A)e), and the absence of pure Ni or Fe peaks indicate formation of Ni-Fe alloys in their mixture. Similar to above observation, addition of MgO into 0.77%(Ni68Fe32) reduced the intensity of Ni-Fe alloy peak. The new peak in a freshly reduced 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) sample (Fig. 9(A)f) was positioned at 43.8° and was broad in nature. The small broad signal toward higher angle also indicates presence of some pure Ni and Fe particles. However, a distinct peak at 44° in the used catalyst with enhanced intensity was observed (Fig. 9(A)g). The signals with the maximum intense peaks at 44.1 ((221) plane in Pm-3 m lattice) and 43.8° were characterized as FeNi3 (PDF 00-063-3244) and FeNi (PDF 01-071-8321) alloy phases, respectively. The intensities at higher angles corresponding to above alloys were not visible. As FeNi3 phase was partly formed in freshly reduced 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) catalyst along with little amount of Ni and Fe metals as separate phases, the broad overlapping peaks did not allow to quantify alloy formed in the pretreatment process. However, more FeNi3 phase and larger particle formation (narrower peak) were observed at high temperatures during time-on-stream giving higher intensity in the used catalyst. The average crystallite size of FeNi3 was 20 nm in the used catalyst. The Ni-Fe alloy related peaks had very low intensity, and their characterization was incomplete in the MgO containing sample. To confirm the formation of the alloy in these catalyst mixtures, XRD of the unsupported mixture of Ni45Fe21Mg34, Ni72Mg28, and Fe72Mg28 compositions reduced in H2 (without Carbo HSP) are presented in Fig. 9(B). The peak was shifted from 44.6° in Ni metal in Ni72Mg28 catalyst to 44° from the alloy particles formed in Ni45Fe21Mg34 catalyst. The absence of Fe pattern (see reflections at 65, 82.4°) in the Ni45Fe21Mg34 mixture is a clear indication that Fe easily forms solid solution with Ni. This observation in the catalyst mixture further indicates that FeNi3 alloy is formed on the Carbo HSP support. Therefore, formation of FeNi3 alloy in 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34)/Carbo HSP is highly possible. The quantification of the FeNi3 alloy was also necessary. By comparing the intensity of FeNi3 alloy in 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34), it was only 42% compared to the same in 0.77%(Ni68Fe32), as both catalysts contain same amount of Ni. This means that significant amount of Ni may be interacting with MgO by forming Mg1-xNixO2 solid solution. However, the MgO phase was not detected by XRD indicating high dispersion or absence of crystallinity. 3.2.3 TPR analysis Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) profiles of the pure Carbo HSP support as well as the catalyst 0.75%Ni, 0.75%Fe, 0.77%(Ni68Fe32), 1.15%(Ni72Mg28), 1.15%(Fe72Mg28), and 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) impregnated on Carbo HSP catalysts are presented in Fig. 10 . The quantitative analysis of total reductions as well as impregnated metal components only (excluding Carbo HSP reduction) under reductions up to 900 °C is presented in Table 2 . As a reference, a pure NiO profile (dotted line) was also incorporated in the figure. The surface reduction on Carbo HSP produces a small peak at 625 °C with the bulk of the reduction occurring above 735 °C (Fig. 10a). Total reduction of the reducible oxides in the support up to 850 °C corresponds to 272 μmol H2 gcat −1. By addition of Ni, Fe, or Ni-Fe onto the Carbo HSP support, reduction occurred at lower temperatures. While the NiO-impregnated catalyst (Fig. 10b) was reduced in the temperature range between 350 °C and 600 °C, the reduction of FeOx (Fig. 10c) occurred between 450 °C and 770 °C. Two reduction peaks in the 0.77%(Ni68Fe32) catalyst (Fig. 9d) at 430 °C and 550 °C indicate separate reductions in the NiO and FeOx species, respectively. It also indicates that presence of NiO decreased the reduction temperature of FeOx to 550 °C in 0.77%(Ni68Fe32), from 680 °C in the 0.75%Fe catalyst (see Fig. 10c & d). Total reductions were increased to yield an equivalent of 620, 860 and 780 μmol H2 gcat −1 in Ni, Fe, and Ni-Fe impregnated catalysts, respectively. Thus, total reductions were higher than expected from the impregnated metal oxides plus support, indicating significant reduction of the support in the presence of Ni, Fe, or Ni-Fe. With MgO addition along with Ni, Fe, and Ni-Fe on Carbo HSP, the reduction of impregnated metal oxides became difficult, especially in Ni-containing catalysts, shifting toward higher temperatures. Thus, total reductions were found to be 236, 800, and 540 μmol H2 gcat −1 in Ni-Mg, Fe-Mg, and Ni-Fe-Mg impregnated catalysts, respectively. By subtracting the support reduction of fresh Carbo HSP, it was found that 56% of the NiO was reduced in 1.15%(Ni72Mg28) as compared to that in 0.75%Ni/Carbo catalyst (see Table 2). Similarly, a 47% reduction was observed in 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) as compared to 0.77%(Ni68Fe32) catalyst. The lower extent of reduction of NiO in presence of MgO was similar to that found in earlier studies [47,54–57]. The formation of Mg1-xNixO solid solution was responsible for the lower extent of reduction due to strong interaction and therefore, full reduction of NiO was not achieved below 900 °C. FeOx reduction in Fe-Mg/Carbo remained unaffected, and therefore, total reduction of FeOx was nearly 100% as compared with Fe/Carbo HSP. This result is obtained since FeOx cannot form a solid solution with NiO. The slow reduction of NiO in Ni-Fe-MgO catalyst can form small Ni particles with a high dispersion after reduction pretreatment. This is consistent with the XRD profiles of the respective catalysts which showed small intensity with broad peaks. 3.2.4 SEM analysis In Fig. 11 , SEM images of freshly reduced samples of 0.75%Ni, 0.77%(Ni68Fe32), and 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) (both fresh and spent) catalysts are presented. The images indicate that particles are agglomerated making larger assemblies with different shapes on Carbo HSP surface. In Fig. 11(a & b), pure Ni and Ni-Fe particles were agglomerated into large assemblies in 0.75%Ni and 0.77%(Ni68Fe32) catalysts are shown. The surface morphologies in the MgO- containing catalysts indicate the presence of small particles. Therefore, Ni-Fe is highly dispersed as MgO promotes formation of small particles. The surface morphology did not change much in the spent catalyst (Fig. 11d) as compared to the freshly reduced sample (Fig. 11c). Coke deposition is a common problem in Ni catalysts. There was no coke deposition in the catalyst as was visible in the earlier study [39]. Therefore, MgO helps keeping Ni and Ni-Fe particles well dispersed under at high temperature as well as stop coke formation on catalyst surface. 3.2.5 FTIR spectra analysis The addition of MgO component into Ni-Fe mixture was very beneficial for enhancing catalytic activity and it makes a significant difference as a promoter as compared with other promoter oxides like CaO, SrO and BaO. The adsorption of H2O plays a critical role in the reforming reaction and therefore hydrophilicity of the promoter surface needed to be investigated. In Fig. 12 the IR profiles of MgO, CaO, SrO and BaO oxides are shown after moisture adsorption by exposing to air. Clearly, MgO form Mg(OH)2, gives a large OH signal at 3699 cm−1 as compared with much smaller signal for Ca(OH)2 formed in CaO at 3643 cm−1 [58]. This type of hydroxide peaks were not observed in SrO and BaO. A very large signal of Carbonate was observed in CaO, SrO and BaO compounds in 1400–1600 cm−1 region. Only a small signal related to carbonate was observed in MgO. This indicates formation of carbonate layers, which might have prevented H2O adsorption on the surface of CaO, SrO and BaO. 3.2.6 CO2 TPD analysis It was important to understand the role of basicity in MgO as compared with other promoters like CaO, SrO and BaO oxides. The activity of the promoter is diminished if it tends to form more carbonate species in the surface. In Fig. 13 the CO2 TPD in the Ni-Fe-MgO, Ni-Fe-CaO and Ni-Fe-SrO catalysts in the powder form is presented. The temperature of CO2 desorption and the area under the peak correspond to the strength of Carbonate species. Clearly, only a small amount of CO2 is desorbed from MgO surface above 600 °C. As we have observed in the IR that MgO is easily converted to Mg(OH)2 (see Fig. 12) and therefore, only small amount of carbonate species is formed. On the other hand, CaO and SrO form more stable carbonate, as the desorption peaks with relatively higher intensity extend above 900 °C. Hence, least basicity of MgO makes it a very special as compared with other oxides like CaO, SrO and BaO. 4 Discussion The current catalyst formulation comprised of Ni, Fe, and MgO has demonstrated high tar removal performance in terms of high toluene conversion activity and stability against coke deposition during reforming reaction. Both, MgO and Fe played a critical role in the overall performance of the Ni-based catalyst. In this study, MgO was found to have exceptionally high promoting effect on the activity of Ni as compared with other alkaline earth metal oxides like CaO, SrO, and BaO oxides. It was an observation that Ni-MgO catalysts had initially a high activity, but diminished significantly within 1 h on stream while collecting the final data. The black coke formation visible in the catalyst bed was responsible for the decline. The coke formation was significantly diminished by the incorporation of Fe into the Ni-MgO formulation. TPO measurements with the 1.17%(Ni45Fe21Mg34) composition after 48 h of time-on-stream did not show any signal, providing additional. The FeNi3 alloy in contact with MgO species could be responsible for reducing coke formation in the catalyst. The role of Fe addition into Ni catalyst was studied previously. It indicated that mildly oxidizing Fe can help in accumulating oxygen species on the Ni surface and therefore prevent coke formation during reaction [25,29]. The role of MgO in improving the tar removal performance of the catalyst is not completed discerned, but it does appears that the ability to hold the hydroxyl molecule is an important effect. As MgO is an irreducible oxide, very little electronic interaction with Ni/Fe metal should occur. Such high activity cannot be due to high dispersion of Ni alone. In fact, MgO lattice contains a high density of oxide ion vacancy on the surface, known for providing adsorption sites for H2O [59–61]. IR spectra of MgO indicated that Mg(OH)2 was formed easily in MgO. On the contrary, such hydroxide species were not observed, rather a strong layer of carbonate species was formed on CaO, SrO and BaO surfaces. As hydrocarbons are easily dissociated on Ni surfaces, they can react with adjacent H2O molecules adsorbed on MgO at the interface to form COx. Therefore, the most probable mechanism on the catalyst surface is as follows: CHx → C + (x/2) H2 [V]MgO + H2O → H2O* C + H2O* → CO + H2 +  [V]MgO where [V]MgO is the oxygen vacancy site. 5 Conclusions MgO was found to be a much superior promoter for a Ni-Fe metals combination as compared to other alkaline earth metal oxides CaO, SrO, and BaO. The Ni-Fe-Mg oxide mixture impregnated on CARBO HSP contains an optimized composition of Ni, Fe, and MgO in the % wt. ratio of 45:21:34 as represented by 1.17% (Ni45Fe21Mg34)/Carbo HSP. This composition demonstrated the highest activity for reforming of toluene in the producer gas as compared to a reference catalyst. Further, it showed excellent toluene conversion of nearly 100% for at least 48 h, and there was no visible coke deposition leading to deactivation of the catalyst. TPR observations of the prepared Ni-Fe-Mg catalysts indicate strong interaction between Ni, Fe, and Mg in the oxide form, which may be responsible for shifting the reduction to higher temperature and formation of smaller Ni-Fe metal particles as compared to catalysts without MgO. The reduced phase of the catalyst contains FeNi3 alloy phase and appears to be responsible for coke resistance of the catalyst. The reason for the high rate of toluene conversion over this catalyst is most probably due to the high rate of adsorption of H2O which can then react with carbon species generated by CC bond breaking on the Ni surface. The high concentration of defect sites in MgO is considered as providing active sites for H2O adsorption, helping removal of coke species from Ni surface at a faster rate, leading to high activity of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A Ni-Fe-Mg material, supported on a ceramic substrate, suitable for application in a gasifier or reforming reactor was evaluated as a catalyst for tar decomposition via steam reforming. Experiments were conducted in a laboratory-scale fixed-bed reactor using simulated producer gas containing toluene and ethylene as tar surrogates. The catalyst was prepared by wet-impregnation and characterized by analytical techniques to include: BET, XRD, TPR, and SEM. The elemental composition of Ni, Fe, and MgO was optimized for maximum activity and stability. The optimized catalyst composition contained Ni, Fe, and MgO in the ratio 45:21:34 by weight. The observed catalyst activity was superior in comparison to other alkaline earth metal promoters: CaO, SrO, and BaO as well as a reference catalyst, Ni-K-MgO, in the temperature range between 600 and 800 °C. Time on stream with the optimized composition showed sustained tar (toluene + ethylene) conversion of near 100% at 750 °C for at least 48 h, indicating no coke formation. The coke formation affinity of Ni was reduced by the presence of the FeNi3 alloy. The enhanced performance with MgO is attributed to the strong adsorption of H2O forming Mg(OH)2 species facilitated on the oxide ion vacancy site of MgO acting as oxygen exchange site.
coredata.dc:title: High performance Ni-Fe-Mg catalyst for tar removal in producer gas
